content.question: Which element, <math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math> or <math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math>, has the lower boiling point, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math>, because it has a smaller, less polarizable electron cloud than <math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math>

<math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math>, because its atoms have a faster average speed at a given temperature than <math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math> atoms

<math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math>, because it has a larger, more polarizable electron cloud than <math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math>

<math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math>, because its atoms have a slower average speed at a given temperature than <math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math> atoms

content.answer: <math alttext="N e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ne</mi></math>, because it has a smaller, less polarizable electron cloud than <math alttext="X e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Xe</mi></math>

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
